simulation_equations: k(T, den) = DF * exp(-((DH_U2TS - T * DS_U2TS + DCp_U2TS * (T - T0 - T * ln(T/T0)) + m_U2TS * den) / (R * T)))
DG(T, den) = DH - T * DS + DCp * (T - T0 - T * ln(T/T0)) - m * den

constants_required.name: DH_U2TS
constants_required.description: Enthalpy change from unfolded to transition state
constants_required.value_or_range: 20 to 60 kcal/mol (typical range for protein L-like proteins)

constants_required.name: DS_U2TS
constants_required.description: Entropy change from unfolded to transition state

constants_required.name: DCp_U2TS
constants_required.description: Heat capacity change from unfolded to transition state
constants_required.value_or_range: 0.3 to 1.5 kcal/(mol*K) (fraction of native state DCp)

constants_required.name: m_U2TS
constants_required.value_or_range: 0.3 to 0.7 kcal/(mol*M) (fraction of native state m-value)

constants_required.name: DH
constants_required.description: Enthalpy change for native state formation

constants_required.name: DS
constants_required.description: Entropy change for native state formation

constants_required.name: DCp
constants_required.description: Heat capacity change for native state formation

variables_to_vary.name: DG_target
variables_to_vary.description: Target free energy of folding for constant stability conditions

variables_to_vary.name: DCp_U2TS_values
variables_to_vary.description: Different heat capacity values to test proportionality

procedure_steps: Step 1: Initialize all constants (R, T0, DF, DH_U2TS, DS_U2TS, DCp_U2TS, m_U2TS, DH, DS, DCp, m) with values from the constants_required list
Step 2: Create temperature array T ranging from 278 K to 323 K with 20-30 points
Step 3: For uncorrected analysis - fix denaturant concentration (e.g., den=0 M) and compute k(T, den) for all temperatures using the folding rate equation
Step 4: For stability-corrected analysis - for each temperature T, solve for denaturant concentration den that maintains constant DG using DG(T, den) = DG_target (use numerical root finding)
Step 5: Compute k(T, den) at each (T, den) pair that satisfies constant stability condition
Step 6: Create Arrhenius plots: plot ln(k) vs 1/T for both uncorrected (constant den) and corrected (constant DG) conditions
Step 7: Perform linear regression on both plots to extract slopes: slope_uncorrected and slope_corrected
Step 8: Calculate activation enthalpies: DH_activation_uncorrected = -R * slope_uncorrected and DH_activation_corrected = -R * slope_corrected
Step 9: Compute difference: Delta_DH_activation = DH_activation_corrected - DH_activation_uncorrected
Step 10: Repeat steps 3-9 for multiple values of DCp_U2TS to test proportionality hypothesis
Step 11: Plot Delta_DH_activation vs DCp_U2TS to verify linear relationship

Step 12: Generate visualizations: (a) Arrhenius plots comparing corrected vs uncorrected, (b) ln(k) vs T at constant DG, (c) denaturant concentration vs temperature along constant stability contours, (d) Delta_DH_activation vs DCp_U2TS showing proportionality
expected_outcomes: The simulation should reveal: (1) Linear Arrhenius plots (ln(k) vs 1/T) under constant stability conditions (constant DG), confirming the hypothesis that stability-corrected kinetics follow simple Arrhenius behavior. (2) Non-linear or different slope Arrhenius plots at constant denaturant concentration (uncorrected), demonstrating the effect of stability changes. (3) Systematic differences between corrected and uncorrected activation enthalpies (Delta_DH_activation), with corrected values being more accurate representations of the intrinsic folding barrier. (4) A linear relationship between Delta_DH_activation and DCp_U2TS, confirming that the difference in activation enthalpies is proportional to the heat capacity change of the transition state. (5) The magnitude of Delta_DH_activation should scale with the temperature range and DCp_U2TS value, typically ranging from 5-20 kcal/mol for protein L-like systems. (6) Constant stability contours in (T, den) space should show increasing denaturant concentration with increasing temperature to maintain constant DG, reflecting the temperature-dependent stabilization forces.
